name: Datagram Congestion Control Protocol
summary: A transport layer protocol in the Internet protocol suite designed for applications that require reliable congestion control for datagram traffic, without providing full reliability or ordered delivery like TCP.
purpose: Provide a message-oriented, congestion-controlled transport mechanism for applications that need timely delivery without full reliability guarantees

handshake.description: DCCP uses a 4-way handshake to establish a connection and exchange initial sequence numbers and feature negotiation options.
steps: Step 1 (Request): Client sends a request packet to the server with supported features.
Step 2 (Response): Server responds with an acknowledgement and its supported features.
Step 3 (Ack): Client acknowledges the server's response.
Step 4 (Confirm): Server confirms the acknowledgement and the connection is established.

fields.name: Sequence Number
fields.description: Used to order datagrams and detect loss

fields.name: Checksum
fields.description: Used for error-checking of header and payload

fields.name: Reserved / Flags
fields.description: Control flags indicating packet type and features

fields.name: Options
fields.description: Negotiated features for congestion control, timestamps, etc.

structure.header: Source Port, Destination Port, Sequence Number, Checksum, Reserved/Flags, Options

usage: Streaming media applications that require timely delivery with congestion control
Telephony or video applications that prefer reduced latency over guaranteed delivery
Applications that need congestion control but do not require full reliability like TCP
pitfalls: Limited support in operating systems and network devices
No built-in ordering or full reliability
Requires additional security layers for encryption and authentication
Overhead higher than UDP due to congestion control mechanisms
